natural problem: Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles?
natural solution: Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance rate time :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 20"
and h1 : "rate = 60"
and h2 : "distance = rate * time"
shows  "time = 1 / 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes distance rate time :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 20"
and h1 : "rate = 60"
and h2 : "distance = rate * time"
shows  "time = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A car travels a distance of 20 miles at a constant speed of 60 miles per hour. How long does it take for the car to complete the journey? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$ of an hour.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
shows  "20 = (distance / speed) * 60"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
shows  "20 = (distance / speed) * 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If a car is traveling at a constant speed of 60 miles per hour, how long does it take to travel 20 miles? The final answer is 20 minutes.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed distance time_minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "time_minutes = distance / speed * 60"
shows  "time_minutes = 20"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes speed distance time_minutes :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "time_minutes = distance / speed * 60"
shows  "time_minutes = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If a car travels at a constant speed of 60 miles per hour and covers a distance of 20 miles, how many minutes does it take for the car to complete the journey? The final answer is 20 minutes.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distance speed time :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 20"
and h1 : "speed = 60"
and h2 : "distance = speed * (time / 60)"
shows  "time = 20"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20

 *)

theorem
fixes distance speed time :: real
assumes h0 : "distance = 20"
and h1 : "speed = 60"
and h2 : "distance = speed * (time / 60)"
shows  "time = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: If you are traveling at a speed of 60 miles per hour, how much time (in minutes) will it take to cover a distance of 20 miles? The final answer is 20 minutes.

theorem
fixes rate distance time :: real
assumes h0 : "rate = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "distance = rate * (time / 60)"
shows  "time = 20"

 ### Proof

theorem
fixes rate distance time :: real

shows  "time = 20"

a_4.informal problem: A car is traveling at a constant speed of 60 miles per hour. How long will it take to cover a distance of 20 miles? The final answer is 20 minutes.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed distance time :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * speed = 60 * distance"
and h1 : "1 * time = 60 * distance"
shows  "20 * time = 20 * speed"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes speed distance time :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * speed = 60 * distance"
and h1 : "1 * time = 60 * distance"
shows  "20 * time = 20 * speed"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If a vehicle travels at a constant speed, and it takes 60 times longer to cover a certain distance than the time it takes to cover that distance, find the relationship between the speed and time when the vehicle travels 20 times the original distance. The final answer is that 20 times the time is equal to 20 times the speed.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rate distance :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * distance = 60 * rate"
shows  "20 * rate = 20 * (1 / 3)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes rate distance :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * distance = 60 * rate"
shows  "20 * rate = 20 * (1 / 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the distance covered at a constant rate in 20 minutes, if the distance covered in 1 hour is 60 times the rate. The final answer is $\frac{20}{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "1 * hour = 60 * minute"
shows  "distance / speed = 20 * minute"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "speed = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "1 * hour = 60 * minute"
shows  "distance / speed = 20 * minute"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How long does it take to travel a distance of 20 miles at a speed of 60 miles per hour? Express your answer in minutes. The final answer is 20 minutes.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * distance = 60 * speed"
shows  "20 * distance = 20 * speed"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes speed distance :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * distance = 60 * speed"
shows  "20 * distance = 20 * speed"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the relationship between the distance and speed when the distance is 60 times the speed. If you multiply both distance and speed by 20, what is the new relationship between the distance and speed? The final answer is that the distance is still 20 times the speed.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rate distance time :: real
assumes h0 : "rate = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "time = 20"
and h3 : "rate * (time / 60) = distance"
shows  "time = 20"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Jeremiah is riding in a car that is traveling 60 miles per hour. At this rate, how many minutes will it take him to travel 20 miles? The final Answer is 20
 ### Proof
 Distance equals rate times time, so the trip will take $$\frac{20\text{ mi. }}{60\text{ mph}}=\frac{1}{3}\text{ hours}.$$  One-third of an hour is $\boxed{20}$ minutes.
 *)

theorem
fixes rate distance time :: real
assumes h0 : "rate = 60"
and h1 : "distance = 20"
and h2 : "time = 20"
and h3 : "rate * (time / 60) = distance"
shows  "time = 20"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If you are traveling at a rate of 60 miles per hour and cover a distance of 20 miles, how long does it take to travel that distance in minutes? The final answer is 20 minutes.
